raw_text:
Ore costs hit global steel firms
 
 Shares in steel firms have dropped worldwide amid concerns that higher iron ore costs will hit profit growth.
 
 Shares in Germany's ThyssenKrupp, the UK's Corus and France's Arcleor fell while Japan's Nippon Steel slid after it agreed to pay 72% more for iron ore. China's Baoshan Iron and Steel Co. said it was delaying a share sale because of weak market conditions, adding it would raise steel prices to offset ore costs. The threat of higher raw material costs also hit industries such as carmakers. France's Peugeot warned that its profits may decline this year as a result of the higher steel, plastic and commodity prices.
 
 Steelmakers have been enjoying record profits as demand for steel has risen, driven by the booming economies of countries such as China and India. Steel prices rose by 8% globally in January alone and by 24% in China.
 
 The boom times are far from over, but analysts say that earnings growth may slow. The share price fall was initially triggered by news that two of the world's biggest iron ore suppliers had negotiated contracts at much-higher prices. Miners Rio Tinto and Cia. Vale Do Rio Dolce (CVRD) this week managed to boost by 72% the price of their iron ore, a key component of steel. Analysts had expected Japan's Nippon to agree to a price rise of between 40% and 50%. Steel analyst Peter Fish, director of Sheffield-based consulting group MEPS, said the extent of CVRD's price rise was "uncharted territory", adding that the steel industry "hasn't seen an increase of this magnitude probably in 50 years". Analysts now expect other iron ore producers, such as Australia's BHP Billiton, to seek annual price rises of up to 70%.
 
 The news triggered the share price weakness. "It sparked worries that steel makers might not be able to increase product prices further [ to cover rising ore costs]" explained Kazuhiro Takahashi of Daiwa Securities SMBC. In Europe, Arcelor shed 2.1% to 17.58 euros in Paris, with ThyssenKrupp dropping 1.7% to 16.87 euros. In London, Corus fell 2.2% to 55.57 pence. Japan's biggest steel company Nippon Steel lost 2.5% to 270 yen, with closest rival JFE Holdings down 3.4%. China's Baoshan, the country's largest steel producer, said that the uncertainty surrounding the industry has prompted it to pull its planned share sale. The firm had been expected to offer 22.5bn yuan ($2.7bn) worth of shares to investors. No date has been given for when the 5 billion shares will come to the market. Baoshan stock climbed on news of the delay and its decision to increase the price of its steel by 10%.
llama3.2:1b: Ore costs are affecting global steel firms, leading to a decline in their share prices. Shares in major steel companies such as ThyssenKrupp, Corus, and Arcleor have dropped, while others like Nippon Steel and Baoshan Iron and Steel Co. have slid due to higher iron ore costs. China's steel production is also expected to increase, leading to a potential price rise of up to 70% for certain producers.
llama3.2:3b: Global steel firms' shares have dropped amid concerns over higher iron ore costs, with ThyssenKrupp, Corus, Arcleor falling; Nippon Steel losing 2.5% after agreeing to pay 72% more for iron ore; and China's Baoshan Iron and Steel Co. delaying a share sale due to weak market conditions, which will raise steel prices to offset ore costs; profit growth may slow as earnings growth is expected to decline.
gemma2:2b: Steel firms are facing pressure from higher iron ore costs, leading to declines in their share prices. This surge in ore prices is attributed to increased demand for steel driven by booming economies like China and India. While steel prices have been soaring, analysts predict earnings growth may slow down as the industry struggles with rising raw material costs.  Major iron ore suppliers Rio Tinto and CVRD secured price hikes of 72% for their product, causing concern among steelmakers. This trend is expected to encourage other producers to seek annual price rises of up to 70%. Some companies are even delaying share sales due to uncertainty in the market.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Shares in steel firms have fallen worldwide amid concerns about higher iron ore costs hitting profit growth. Shares in Germany's ThyssenKrupp, Japan's Nippon Steel, and France's Arcleor fell after agreeing to pay more for iron ore. China's Baoshan Iron & Steel Co. delayed a share sale due to weaker market conditions, adding it would raise steel prices to offset ore costs. The threat of higher raw material costs also hit industries such as carmakers and Europe's largest steel producer, Nippon Steel.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ore costs have hit global steel firms, causing their share prices to drop worldwide due to concerns about higher iron ore costs. Steelmakers are experiencing record profits but expect earnings growth to slow as they face pressure from rising raw material costs. Analysts predict other iron ore producers will seek annual price rises of up to 70%.
qwen2.5:3b: Ore costs have hit global steel firms, causing a decline in their share prices due to concerns over increased raw material expenses impacting profit growth. Steelmakers are facing higher iron ore prices from suppliers, leading analysts to expect annual price rises of up to 70% for other producers. This has led to declines in various steel firm shares and delayed or cancelled share sales, as companies struggle to increase product prices to cover rising costs. The threat of reduced earnings growth is anticipated despite the ongoing demand-driven boom times.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. Let me start by reading through the entire passage carefully.

First, it mentions that Ore costs have hit global steel firms because higher iron ore prices are expected to affect profits. The shares in several steel companies like Germany's ThyssenKrupp, UK's Corus, France's Arcleor, Japan's Nippon Steel, and China's Baoshan Iron/Steel Co. dropped.

I notice that the steel industry is doing well with rising demand from countries like China and India, but there are concerns about raw material costs which could slow earnings growth.

Reading further, it mentions that two major iron ore suppliers increased their prices by 72%, while analysts expect others to increase by up to 70%. This news caused some steel companies to drop their shares because of the higher costs.

There's also talk about how rising prices would offset ore costs and the impact on industries like carmakers. French Peugeot warned that profits might fall if steel, plastic, and commodities prices rise too much.

The summary should include the main points: Ore costs increasing steel profits, share price drops due to news of supplier price hikes, industry's success despite cost concerns, expected earnings growth, and the ripple effects on other sectors.

I need to make sure not to include any explanations or formatting. Just a clean summary in plain text.
</think>

Ore costs have increased global steel firms due to rising iron ore prices, leading to profit drops as shares in companies like ThyssenKrupp, Corus, Arcleor, Nippon Steel, and Baoshan Iron/Steel Co. fell. Analysts expect earnings growth to slow due to higher raw material costs. The share price weakness was partly triggered by supplier price hikes of 72% for Rio Tinto and Vale Do Rio Dolce. Other producers expect annual price increases up to 70%. Rise in prices could offset ore costs, benefiting carmakers. French Peugeot warned declining profits if steel, plastic, and commodities prices increase significantly. The period is far from over; earnings growth may slow as raw material costs rise.
tinyllama:1.1b: The global steel industry is facing rising iron ore costs, which have led to a decline in share prices for several major steelmakers. In January alone, steel prices rose by 8% globally and rose by 24% in China. The threat of higher raw material costs also impacted the industrial sectors such as automobiles and industry. Earnings growth may slow down due to this decline in share prices.
tinydolphin:1.1b: ThyssenKrupp, Corus, and several other iron ore producers worldwide experienced steep drops in their share prices after new contracts were announced with major suppliers at higher prices. Market concerns about increased costs for raw materials like iron ore are expected to have an impact on industries such as automotive and steel production. In recent years, the global steel industry has seen profits soar due to rising demand from China and India. However, the current price spike is expected to slow down earnings growth and may prompt some producers to raise their prices in response.
phi:2.7b: Ore costs have caused a drop in the global steel industry, with companies like ThyssenKrupp, Corus, and Arcleor's shares dropping due to higher iron ore prices. Japan'S Nippon Steel also saw its share price fall after agreeing to pay 72% more for iron ore. The steel industry has been enjoying record profits, but analysts say that earnings growth may slow down due to the higher raw material costs. The rise in prices of iron ore caused shares to plummet initially, with some companies, like BHP Billiton and Cia. Vale do Rio Dolce (CVRD), agreeing to negotiate contracts at much-higher prices, causing more concern. Analysts expect these price rises to slow down the industry's growth. This news led to drops in share prices of steel firms worldwide, particularly in Japan. China'S largest steel producer Baoshan also delayed a planned share sale due to market conditions. As a result of higher costs, France'S Peugeot warned that its profits might decline this year, and the car industry is already feeling the impact. Analysts predict slower growth for the industry as a whole, with lower earnings than previously expected due to increased raw material prices.
orca-mini:3b: Global steel firms face higher iron ore costs that could impact their profit growth, causing shares to drop worldwide. ThyssenKrupp, Corus, and Arcelor fell in Germany, the UK, and France respectively, while Nippon Steel slid after agreeing to pay 72% more for iron ore. The threat of higher raw material costs also hit industries such as carmakers. Peugeot warned that its profits may decline this year due to high steel, plastic, and commodity prices. The news triggered share price weakness and spurred concerns about steel makers' ability to increase product prices further to cover rising ore costs.
hermes3:3b: Iron ore cost rise impacts global steel shares, leading to price drops for firms like ThyssenKrupp, Corus, Arcelor, Nippon Steel etc., as increased costs may slow earnings growth.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Steel firms' shares dropped worldwide due to concerns that higher iron ore costs will hinder profit growth. Germany's ThyssenKrupp, the UK's Corus, and France's Arcelor fell, while Japan's Nippon Steel slid after agreeing to pay 72% more for iron ore. China's Baoshan Iron and Steel Co. delayed a share sale and raised steel prices due to weak market conditions and higher ore costs. The boom in demand for steel has led to record profits, but analysts predict earnings growth may slow down. The extent of the price rise by Rio Tinto and CVRD was unprecedented, leading experts to believe other iron ore producers will seek annual price increases of up to 70%. The news sparked worries that steel makers might not be able to increase product prices further to cover rising ore costs.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Global steel firms' shares have dropped due to concerns over rising iron ore costs impacting profits. Companies like ThyssenKrupp, Corus, Arcelor, and Nippon Steel saw declines, with Nippon agreeing to a 72% price hike for iron ore. China's Baoshan Iron and Steel delayed a share sale and announced steel price increases to offset costs. Higher raw material prices also affected industries like car manufacturing, with Peugeot warning of potential profit declines. Steel demand remains strong, but earnings growth may slow. The price surge was driven by Rio Tinto and CVRD securing a 72% increase in iron ore prices, far exceeding expectations. Analysts predict other suppliers, like BHP Billiton, will seek similar hikes. The uncertainty led to share price declines across major steel firms, while Baoshan's stock rose after postponing its share sale and raising steel prices by 10%.
stablelm2:1.6b: Global steel firms face higher iron ore costs, leading to share price falls in ThyssenKrupp, Corus, Arcelor, Nippon Steel, Japan's JFE Holdings, and Baoshan Iron & Steel Co. These companies have agreed to pay more for iron ore due to weak market conditions. Higher steel, plastic, and commodity prices threaten earnings growth despite record profits from rising demand in countries like China and India. Analysts expect other iron ore producers to seek up to 25% price increases annually.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Global steel firms' share prices have dropped due to escalating iron ore costs, threatening profit growth. Notable declines include ThyssenKrupp (Germany), Corus (UK), Arcelor (France), Nippon Steel (Japan), and China's Baoshan Iron and Steel Co., which delayed a share sale amid weak market conditions and plans to raise steel prices. Higher raw material costs also impacted carmakers, with France's Peugeot warning of potential profit declines due to increased steel, plastic, and commodity prices. The steel industry, previously enjoying record profits from rising demand in countries like China and India (steel prices up 24% globally and 8% in January), now faces earnings growth slowdown. This was triggered by Rio Tinto and CV Dole's significant price hikes for iron ore, with analysts expecting further annual increases of up to 70% from producers like BHP Billiton.
